result.execSummary:
The defendant Daniel S Behrend was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Retail Theft - Intentionally Take (<=$500), a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.50(1m)(b).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: IMPOSED AND STAYED. With Huber and good time.

miscConds.notes: $200 DNA surcharge and court costs remitted. $67 VW surcharge to be collected by the Dept of Corrections.
Not to be at any Home Depot.

Defendant shall complete a risk and needs assessment and comply with care plan goals related to prioritized need areas identified. DNA on file. Any other conditions DOC, Probation/Parole Department may impose.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Daniel S Behrend

records.addlTxt: Notice of right to seek postconviction relief

Court reporter Teri Groves. Defendant Daniel S Behrend in court.  Attorney Will Rice Anderson in court for Daniel S Behrend.  Attorney Timothy Verhoff in court for State of Wisconsin. Plea Questionnaire & Waiver of Rights Signed. Def entered a plea of guilty to amended count 1, misdemeanor retail theft.  Court accepted defendant's plea, found and adjudged defendant guilty. 

Victim Rights Compliance

COUNT #1     
Court I/S a sentence of: 
-Serve 120 days in the DCJ, with Huber and good time

-Stayed for 12 months  probation 

CONDITIONS:
-Not to be at any Home Depot
-DNA on file

-Defendant to undergo a risk and needs assessment
-Any other conditions DOC may impose

COURT COSTS:
Ct #1
- All CC and DNA surcharge waived. V/W surcharge due on probation

-Days credit if revoked: Zero days

DE advised of post-conviction rights

[Jaime D.]
